p: Climatic alteration also affects the bunch potential healthiness. Climate variability affects the patterns of plant diseases by changing the geographical distribution of pathogens or affecting the physiology of the hostâ€“pathogen interaction or the pathogen evolution under altered climatic conditions [ 59, 60, 61]. The potential impact of climate change on the use of agrochemicals has both environmental and economic consequences. According to Salinari et al. [ 62], predictable models show an increase in disease pressure from P. viticola; on the other hand, they show a significant decrease of powdery mildew epidemics in the last century [ 57]. Several disease models have been used to simulate future scenarios of plant pathogens epidemics on grape with climate changes [ 59, 62]. In the study area, the total number of phytosanitary treatments increased exponentially in the last 15 years, particularly against the downy mildew. This evidence suggests the importance of the on-farm monitoring and the opportunity to develop decision support innovation for precision viticulture and sustainable productions.
